description:
Gambusia affinis, commonly known as the western mosquitofish or common mosquitofish, is a small freshwater fish species belonging to the family Poeciliidae. It is native to the southeastern United States and northeastern Mexico, but has been widely introduced globally as a biological control agent for mosquitoes.

Gambusia affinis is a small, live-bearing fish, with females typically reaching around 6 cm in length and males being slightly smaller. They have a distinctive, laterally compressed body shape and a large, upturned mouth. The coloration is generally pale to dark brown, with some darker vertical bars or blotches along the sides.

These fish are highly adaptable and can thrive in a variety of aquatic habitats, including ponds, lakes, streams, and even brackish waters. They are primarily surface-dwelling and feed on a variety of small aquatic organisms, including mosquito larvae, which has contributed to their use as a biological control agent.

Gambusia affinis is known for its reproductive strategy, where the females give birth to live young, called "fry." The females can store sperm and produce multiple broods of offspring throughout the breeding season, which can contribute to their rapid population growth and dispersal.

Due to their adaptability and aggressive predatory behavior, Gambusia affinis has been introduced to many parts of the world, where it has sometimes had negative impacts on native species and ecosystems. As a result, its use as a biological control agent has been the subject of ongoing debate and research.
